commentary.line: On behalf of Mani and my co-commentators, Ramakrishnan and Pradeep, this is Sidhant Maheshwari, signing off.
So, that brings us to the end of our coverage of this game. Bangladesh are 1-0 up in the series. Can they make it 2-0 on Sunday? Join us then to find out.

Earlier in the day, Bangladesh posted their highest ODI total, thanks to brilliant hundreds from Tamim Iqbal and Mushfiqur Rahim. Their 178-run partnership for the third wicket was a delight to watch, with Rahim firing on all cylinders. In the end, a few good hits from Shakib and Sabbir helped Bangladesh post 329 on the board.

Rizwan kept batting well from one end, dispatching the bad deliveries to the fence, while keeping out the good ones. However, he didn't get much support from the other end as wickets kept tumbling. In the end Pakistan were bowled out for 250, losing their last 6 wickets for just 33 runs.

Bangladesh deserved this win. Even though Pakistan started off really well, putting together a 50-plus opening stand, Bangladesh picked up two wickets in quick succession to pull things back. Ali and Sohail then tried to consolidate, but Ali got out to Taskin in the 28th over. After that Rizwan and Sohail, both tried to up the ante, but Sohail too perished after reaching his fifty.

Rahim: 'I thought I was really lucky. I thought Tamim deserved it more than me (on winning the Man of the Match award). It is dedicated to my wife. The boys really did a great job. The preparation was really good. If someone fails, someone puts their hand up every time. This was a pressure match for us, but we are happy to win here. The bowlers did a great job as there was nothing for the bowlerson that pitch.'
Mushfiqur Rahim is the Man of the Match for his 77-ball 106

Shakib: 'I thought Tamim and Rahim batted really well. It was a good wicket to bat on, but we never thought that we can score that much. So credit goes to those two. We did well in the field too. All in all, it was a very good team performance. It was a great performance from the batting and bowling unit, it was really professional. Hopefully, we can keep playing like that. We now have the belief that we can win this series. They were hoping for a win and thanks to them for coming down here to support us. I just hope they support us when we don't perform that well too. '

Azhar Ali: 'We made some mistakes in the field. They played really well. We dropped some catches at the wrong time, but credit should go to the Bangladeshi batsmen. There are a few positives, especially Rizwan, who showed his class with the bat. We made some mistakes and hopefully, we can rectify them. As a bowling unit, we made some mistakes. We have only one day and we will try and fix it before the next game.'

The players walk off the field. The Bangladeshis are delighted. They have beaten their opposition comprehensively today. Bangaldesh have beaten Pakistan after 16 years. This is only their second win against Pakistan in ODI history.

45.2   Shakib to Ajmal, out Lbw!! Ajmal has been given out lbw here. He reviews it and Hawk-Eye shows that the ball was hitting the stumps there. It was a flatter delivery on middle and leg, Ajmal looks to pull it through the on-side and misses. The ball hits the pad, the umpire raised his finger after the bowler appealed. Hawk-Eye showed that the ball was clipping the leg stump. The onfield decision stays and Bangladesh win by 79 runs. They go 1-0 up in the 3-match series. Ajmal lbw b Shakib 0(4)
Shakib to Ajmal, THATS OUT!! Lbw!!

It was a yorker outside off, Ajmal squeezes it out towards point and sets off, Junaid was out of his crease too. Junaid was looking to run back as Sabbin charges in from point, picks the ball and fires in a direct-hit at the non-striker's end. The third umpire took his time and decided that it is out as Junaid just about planted his bat when the bails had gone off. Junaid Khan run out (S Rahman) 0(0)
Rubel to Ajmal, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!

The third umpire has been pressed into service for a run-out decision. Junaid probably put his bat inside the crease just in time to save himself there. Wait a minute! It looks closer than it appears. It is touch and go. He has been given out there and Junaid is not a happy man.

Even if it's clipping, the onfield decision will stay. The Hawk-Eye is taking a lot of time for some reason. The Bangladeshi players wait and the decision is out. Welcome back. Bangladesh are in the driver's seat for now. It's not going to be easy for Pakistan to chase this down and if Bangladesh manage to take early wickets, they will put the Pakistani middle-order under a lot of pressure.

Wahab Riaz was the pick of the bowlers for the visitors as he picked up four wickets. Although Junaid Khan and Rahat Ali bowled decently, the returning Saeed Ajmal took a pasting and conceded 67 runs in his last 6 overs. Can Pakistan chase this down? We'll find out in a while.

So Bangladesh have finished with 329/6 - their highest score in ODIs. After opting to bat first, openers Tamim Iqbal and Soumya Sarkar got Bangladesh off to a good start before the latter was run-out. Mahmudullah, who had a wonderful World Cup, threw his wicket away early, but Tamim combined well with Mushfiqur Rahim and the duo thrashed the Pakistani bowlers to all corners as they registered their respective hundreds. They were also involved in a record 178-run stand - the highest for Bangladesh for any wicket in ODIs. Although both perished at the fag end of the innings, Shakib Al Hasan and Sabbir Rahman took the score past 300 with some fine hits.

Pitch Report: There's quite a lot of live grass. There should be good carry and bounce off the deck. The captains will be tempted to play more pacers. The batsmen should be watchful, runs will come as the innings progresses, the team winning the toss might opt to bowl first,' reckons Athar Ali Khan
Teams:
Bangladesh (Playing XI): Tamim Iqbal, Soumya Sarkar, Mahmudullah, Mushfiqur Rahim(w), Shakib Al Hasan(c), Nasir Hossain, Sabbir Rahman, Abul Hasan, Arafat Sunny, Rubel Hossain, Taskin Ahmed
Pakistan (Playing XI): Mohammad Hafeez, Azhar Ali(c), Haris Sohail, Saad Nasim, Fawad Alam, Sarfraz Ahmed(w), Mohammad Rizwan, Wahab Riaz, Junaid Khan, Saeed Ajmal, Rahat Ali
Bangladesh have won the toss and have opted to bat

Both teams have had their share of administrative wrangings and the series will provide them a much needed distraction from events which are out of their control. There's some early team news from the Pakistan camp. Mohammad Rizwan, the wicket-keeper batsman and Saad Nasim, the all-rounder, are set to make their ODI debuts for Pakistan.

On the other hand, hosts, Bangladesh are a confident unit. They put up their best ever performance in the World Cup scalping England before eventually losing to India in the quarter-final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground. Mashrafe Mortaza led an inspired show from the Tigers, but he will be missing today, serving his one-match ban for slow over-rate during the Q/F match against India.

13:45 Local Time, 07:45 GMT, 13:15 IST: It's the beginning of a new era in Pakistan cricket. Misbah-ul-Haq and Shahid Afridi announced their ODI retirements at the end of the 2015 Cricket World Cup. Saeed Ajmal, who missed the sport's biggest tournament after his action was found to be illegal, returns after having rectified his bowling action. Azhar Ali, who wasn't considered good enough to be a part of the 15-member WC squad has been named as the captain. Wicket-keeper batsman, Sarfraz Ahmed, will be his deputy. Also returning to the team is Mohammad Hafeez, who missed the World Cup with an injury.

Preview:
If one looks at Bangladesh's record against Pakistan, it is abysmal. In 47 international matches spread across formats, Bangladesh have registered just one victory and it came in an ODI 16 years ago during the 1999 World Cup match in Northampton. They have lost 25 consecutive ODIs against them since that day. In the list of bogey teams, Pakistan's name is right on top for Bangladesh. However, in a fresh season, it is time for a new beginning.

It is a new era for Pakistan. With Misbah-ul-Haq retiring from ODIs after the end of the World Cup, the team will be led by Azhar Ali, who last played an ODI two years ago. During his time, Azhar has demonstrated a cool head and the tourists will be hoping for some stability in his leadership.

Already, players from both camps are having their say. Shakib Al Hasan said this series was the best opportunity for Bangladesh to register a win over Pakistan. In the opposition camp, allrounder Mohammad Hafeez pointed out that Pakistan have the resources but cautiously stated that Bangladesh are an improved team. On paper, Pakistan are favorites to continue the dominance but Bangladesh will be determined to snap this losing streak. The home team have already made the right start after a BCB XI defeated a full strength Pakistan team by one wicket during a warm-up match in Fatullah on Wednesday.

Venue: Shere Bangla Stadium, Mirpur

Date: April 17, 2015

Time: 14:30 local

Team news:

Bangladesh

Shakib Al Hasan, who was playing for the Kolkata in IPL 8, will come back to lead the team in the first ODI after Mashrafe Moratza was ruled out due to a knee injury. The team will also see Rony Talukdar making his ODI debut. Talukdar was the most consistent performer in the Bangladesh domestic circuit last year when he scored 714 runs in the Dhaka Premier Division while he also made 777 runs in the National Cricket League games. He will partner Tamim Iqbal as Bangladesh search for stability at the top. The batting will once again revolve around the trio of Shakib, Mushfiqur Rahim and Mahmudullah, who became the first Bangladesh player to score consecutive centuries in the World Cup.

Probable XI

1 Tamim Iqbal, 2 Rony Talukdar, 3 Soumya Sarkar, 4 Mahmudullah, 5 Shakib Al Hasan (c), 6 Mushfiqur Rahim (wk), 7 Sabbir Rahman, 8 Nasir Hossain, 9 Rubel Hossain, 10 Abul Hasan, 11 Taskin Ahmed

Pakistan

The scoreline for Pakistan already reads 3-0. They have lost three players heading into the series. Sohaib Maqsood was ruled out due to a fractured wrist while Sohail Khan, who impressed in the 2015 World Cup, will miss the series due to a back injury. During the warm-up game in Fatullah, Yasir Shah sustained a hand injury which required stitches, thus ruling him out for the ODI series.

However, in addition to a new captain, Pakistan will also welcome back Junaid Khan, who missed the World Cup due to a knee injury and Saeed Ajmal, who will play his first international match after remodelling his action. The team will also see some fresh faces in 22-year-old Mohammad Rizwan, the back-up keeper to Sarfraz Ahmed and also 19-year-old Sami Aslam, who captained the Pakistan U-19 team in the 2014 World Cup. The presence of Junaid and Ajmal will be reassuring for a team that has struggled in bilateral series. In the last 13 ODIs, they have won just three games. Pakistan will aim to improve their record in bilateral ODIs in a new season.

Probable XI

1 Mohammad Hafeez, 2 Sami Aslam, 3 Haris Sohail, 4 Azhar Ali (c), 5 Sarfraz Ahmed (wk), 6 Asad Shafiq, 7 Saad Nasim, 8 Wahab Riaz, 9 Saeed Ajmal, 10 Junaid Khan, 11 Rahat Ali/Ehsan Adil

Quotes

"We break down mentally when we lose a practice match abroad. Pakistan might be having the same thought process, which will have some effect on the first game. We will try to play better cricket." - Bangladesh legspinner Sabbir Rahman fires a psychological salvo at Pakistan following a win by the BCB XI over them in Fatullah on Wednesday.

"It might look easy to beat them but they never been as easy. For the last 2-3 years, they have developed into a good team." - Pakistan allrounder Mohammad Hafeez has urged his team not to take Bangladesh lightly.
Teams:

Pakistan (From): Mohammad Hafeez, Azhar Ali(c), Haris Sohail, Saad Nasim, Fawad Alam, Sarfraz Ahmed(w), Asad Shafiq, Wahab Riaz, Junaid Khan, Saeed Ajmal, Rahat Ali, Sami Aslam, Mohammad Rizwan, Ehsan Adil

Bangladesh (From): Tamim Iqbal, Rony Talukdar, Soumya Sarkar, Mahmudullah, Shakib Al Hasan(c), Mushfiqur Rahim(w), Sabbir Rahman, Nasir Hossain, Arafat Sunny, Rubel Hossain, Taskin Ahmed, Abul Hasan, Mominul Haque
